awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Strategies for Successful Large-Scale, Distributed Science and Engineering Projects
awd_abstract_narration:
Large-scale, innovative science and engineering requires collaboration across geographically-distributed, multidisciplinary teams; however, it is very difficult for projects to maintain intellectual cohesion, tight coordination, and integration necessary to manage scalable "virtual" work that is distributed. 

The goal of this project is to help teams to succeed - maximizing efficiency, effectiveness, and innovativeness. This proposal is to develop the capacity for leaders of Centers, Institutes, Labs and other collaborations to plan and pursue transformative research agendas in order to truly create breakthroughs in smart and connected health, cyberphysical systems, smart cities, cybersecurity, big data, environmental sustainability, and across the domains of basic research. Training in design and management of such collaborations will be provided and tools and techniques will be developed. This work will draw on lessons learned from organization science to develop a customized curriculum to help large-scale science and engineering teams effectively and efficiently collaborate at this scale. Using the developed materials, the first of a series of workshops targeting potential principal investigators interested in large-scale Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE)-related projects will be conducted in the fall of 2019.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Large-scale science and engineering research projects have transformative potential in society.  Success in these large research projects depends not just on scientific merit, but also on organizational and institutional factors: stakeholder alignment, performance measurement, project leadership, data management, people development, and bridging across fields and disciplines.  These latter are the focus of the NSF-funded “Leap to Large” workshop series.

The goals of the workshops were to create enduring educational infrastructure for principal investigators (PIs) looking to "make the leap to large" and to equip these prospective PIs with the tools and approaches needed to be effective in doing so.  The infrastructure created includes a set of publicly available videos introducing important concepts and showing how experts in the field apply them.  Over 700 prospective PIs improved their understanding through participation in one or more of the live sessions from which the videos were created. 

The grants targeted for the “Leap to Large” workshop are in the range of $4 million to $10 million, and typically last more than four years.  They are less than 10% of NSF grants, yet have major impact.  They too often lack the strategy, structure, and processes to operate at scale.  While intended for PIs leading large grants, those leading smaller grants can benefit from the workshop series.  

The sessions were successful in drawing participation from Principal Investigators (PIs) who met the desired profile.  When asked in pre-session surveys if they had served as a PI or co-PI on any small or medium grants, 24% of the respondents had served on 1-2 such grants, 35% had served on 3-5 such grants, and 23% had served on more.  Only 13% responding to the first survey had not served on any small or medium grants.  Further, 70% had not served as a PI or co-PI on grants funded at more than $2 million and for more than three years.  Another 27% had done so on 1-2 such grants.  

Attendance at the sessions ranged from approximately 250 to 700.  A core group of 250-350 attended most sessions, and represent a national resource of scholars building capability for large-scale science and engineering research projects. 

During the workshop, a LinkedIn Group was formed (https://www.linkedin.com/groups/12529600/) that now has nearly 200 members, though additional curation and leadership of this community is needed. 

The Stakeholder Bargaining Game Exercise was developed under this grant and is available on request from Joel Cutcher-Gershenfeld (joelcg@brandeis.edu).  We are exploring ways to make it open-access (right now set up by an administrator is needed).

The 90-minute sessions were designed to assist researchers making the "Leap to Large." Each session started with a three-minute animation introducing the theme that can be used for educational purposes.  They include a hypothetical computational chemist, Lucy, making the leap to large.   Each session had one or more keynote speakers, and each was recorded for use by any interested researchers.  Here is a summary of the sessions and available resources:

Session 1: Foundations for large-scale success and impact - April 6, 2021

  • Welcome:  Margaret Martonosi, NSF
  • Keynote:  Stefan Savage, University of California, San Diego
  • Animation: https://youtu.be/GZ5wD2zl6eo 
  • Recording:  Intro – Science Impact: https://youtu.be/f8kcGuCZJ_A 

Session 2: Stakeholder alignment - April 13, 2021

  • Keynote:  Kate Keahey, Argonne National Laboratory
  • Animation: Stakeholders: https://youtu.be/MhVF-UVQ_fk 
  • Recording: Stakeholder Alignment: https://youtu.be/7R0MImbx6vQ  

Session 3: Performance measurement and feedback - April 20, 2021

  • Keynote:  John Towns, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
  • Animation: Measurement: https://youtu.be/PS2eSIiuQ_E 
  • Recording: Performance Measurement: https://youtu.be/QsBvt2rVaZQ 

Session 4: Project leadership - April 27, 2021

  • Keynotes:  Muffet McGraw, University of Notre Dame; Neil Gershenfeld and Sherry Lassiter, MIT Center for Bits and Atoms and Fab Foundation
  • Animation: Leadership: https://youtu.be/mV5mRecqmws 
  • Recording: Project Leadership: https://youtu.be/Ty0wCsG1dVI 

Session 5: Data management - May 4, 2021

  • Panel:  Christine Kirkparick, University of California, San Diego; Steve Diggs, Scripps Institution of Oceanography; and Kerstin Lehnert, Columbia University
  • Keynote:  Kimberly Claffy, University of California, San Diego
  • Animation: Data Management: https://youtu.be/7MWPXESJivg 
  • Recording: Data Management: https://youtu.be/wODhlN1bl58 

Session 6: People development - May 11, 2021

  • Keynote:  Julia Lane, New York University
  • Animation: Workforce: https://youtu.be/6jYyBKsxPTk 
  • Recording: Workforce: https://youtu.be/38LQRaiUbm4 

Session 7: Collaboration across fields and disciplines - May 18, 2021

  • Keynote: Nadya Bliss, Arizona State University
  • Animation: Collaboration: https://youtu.be/BiEiE7IVUNc 
  • Recording: Collaboration: https://youtu.be/YCswgDqmR3g
  • Concluding Comments:  Gurdip Singh, NSF
